text: Fog hangs above the street, amongst the streetlamps.  Apa buildings line the curb, it is very quiet.  In one buildi up, a bedroom light is on.  WE SEE the silhouette of Norm looking out the window.
What kind of a crash was it?
You seen my suitcase?
There's nothing on the news about a crash.  Did he say what airline?
He didn't say much at all.  Honey --
In the closet.  I don't understand, Norman -- why would they call you?
Don't be so supportive, honey.
Well, I can't imagine five years of unemployment --
Four.  Four years --
Four years of unemployment would look too good on a resume.
Keep watching the news.  Are you watching the news?
How are you getting to the airport? You need money for the bus? A tinted-window black SEDAN travels down the street, pull of the apartment building.  A U.S.  NAVY decal is on the
There's a U.S.  Navy car outside, Norman.
What?
Was it a military crash?
I don't know.
They never used to send a Navy car.

head_text.subj: THE LOUD, HARD CHOPPING OF A HELICOPTER PROPELLER

text: Blinding sunlight, as the helicopter WHIPS by, speeding a Pacific Ocean.
Norman, 53, disheveled, unshaven, sits in the back.  He s pamphlet in his hand: "AIRCRASH SURVIVAL: HOW TO COPE". the cockpit, turns to him.
What kinda work you in, Dr. Johnson? Norman quickly stuffs the pamphlet into his dufflebag.
I'm in psychology.  Was.  Still am really, just been a while. (beat)
I treat aircrash survivors.
Oh, so you're that Dr. Johnson.
You've heard of me?
Well, everybody's been talking about that report you wrote.
What report?
Huh?
What report?
You mean you don't know?
Know what? The pilot glances back at him again.
Must be another Johnson then.  Been flying so many scientists out here -- can't keep everyone straight.
Who's everyone?
Physicists, mathematicians, geologists, you name it.
Geologists?  At a plane crash?
Strange, isn't it?  In the middle of the ocean no less.
What the hell would a geologist be doing at a plane crash? Norman looks out the window and sees a group of ships cir water.

The helicopter descends down onto the helipad, wind gusti young, female OFFICER -- holding her hat to her head -- r greet Norman, as he climbs out of the helicopter. She looks down crudely at his shotty, nylon dufflebag.
Any other bags, Dr. Johnson?
Just that.  Careful, it's heavy. She lugs it over her shoulder, no problem.
No other equipment?  Scientific instruments?
No, they didn't say --
This way, sir. Norman follows the officer away from the helipad.
She leads Norman down a flight of stairs.
Captain Barnes wants to see you right away, sir.
Captain who?
Barnes.  He's very eager to meet you. Been calling us every half hour to see if you're arrived.
Really? As they march down a hallway, Norman looks down at his wr tries to smooth it out.
By the way sir, I've read your report.  I think it's brilliant.
What report?
You mean they haven't told you yet?
Told me what? She staightens up, like she might have said too much.
This way, sir.
CAPTAIN HAROLD BARNES, 60s, immaculate, proud of who he i the phone.
How's he look?...  Well, we can't all be officers, can we? (laughs)
They tell me he's brilliant.
Norman stands in front of the door.  The doorplate reads: COMMANDER -- CAPTAIN HAROLD BARNES.  Norman straightens h tie.  Deep breath.
As the door opens, Barnes is putting down the phone, rise desk, as Norman steps inside.
Dr. Norman Johnson.  Welcome aboard. They shake hands.
Thank you, Colonel.
Captain.
Captain.  Right, forgive me. Barnes looks at Norman, sizing him up.  An akward silence
Well, thanks for the opportuninty here -- my wife appreciates it.
Don't thank me, Dr. Johnson.  You weren't my choice.  The Pentagon made me take you.
(smiling)
The Pentagon?  I didn't know I had friends in Washington. Norman tries to laugh as Barnes ushers him to the door...
Come with me.  The team's already waiting.
What team?
Barnes leads Norman down the corridor, lined with OFFICER
What have you been told so far?
The usual.  Plane crash.  Survivers unknown.  Routine stuff really.
Anything else?
Nothing else. A GUARD unlocks a large, steel door.
Captain Barnes.  Dr. Johnson.
Hello. Norman looks at the guard as they proceed through the doo wondering how the guard knows his name.
You talk to any reporters?  Any press?
Press?  No, I haven't. The steel door shuts loudly behind them.
Good.  Security's been our biggest worry.  Now that you're here we can shut this thing down tight.
From what?  What's with all the security?
Well, we don't have all the facts yet. Another GUARD opens up another large steel door...
Barnes leads Norman through the room, crammed with video screens, and grids.  Officers talk into radios.  Technici computers.
We're moving fast considering the storm.
Storm?  What storm?
A cyclone's on it's way in.  I thought they would have told you on the phone.
They didn't tell me anything. Norman tries to keep pace...
We've had divers working around the clock.  Take a look at this... ANGLE ON a large VIDEO SCREEN -- shows a diver walking on floor, holding a bright artificial flashlight.
How deep is he?
A thousand feet.
A thousand?  An airplane crashes into a thousand feet of water -- I don't want to sound pessimistic here, but I assume there are no survivors.
Survivors?  No, I wouldn't think so.
Then why am I here?
What?
What do you need me for? ON THE VIDEO SCREEN -- the diver shines his light on a la OBJECT.
What crashed wasn't an airplane, Dr. Johnson.  It's a bit larger than that. Barnes walks toward a TECHNICIAN, sitting at a keyboard.
(to technician)
Bring up the grid, would you? ANGLE ON THE MONITOR as an IMAGE OF THE CRAFT begins to f
What is it?  A military spacecraft? Like a shuttle or satellite?
Something like that. (beat)
That doesn't surprise you?
Not really, no.  Something of the military crashes in the ocean -- it explains why there was nothing on the news, why you've kept everything a secret...  When did it crash?
As best we can estimate, it crashed four hundred years ago. A beat.
Four hundred?  You're kidding, right? ANGLE ON THE MONITOR -- showing a grid depicting an image and a small layer of ROCK above it.
See this?  Coral.  Geologists measured the coral growth on top of the craft to be over five meters thick.
Geologists?
Coral grows at a rate of two and a half centimeters a year --
-- Wait a second --
-- dating the crash at least that old.
Hold on --
Maybe older --
-- there's got to be some mistake here -- a four hundred year old military spacecraft?  There's no such thing... our space program isn't even forty years old.
Extraordinary, isn't it?
It's impossible.
I'm afraid it is Dr. Johnson... because it's sitting on the bottom of our ocean floor.
Barnes and Norman shuffle down the stairs.
Off the record, I don't mind telling you, this thing scares the shit out of me.
It doesn't make any sense.
We think it might.  That's why we brought you here.  We've assembled your team -- they're waiting for us now.
What team?
The one you recommended.  In the ULF report you wrote for the Bush administration.

ULF report?  Nobody's mentioned that in years.  You mean someone actually read it? As they head down a hallway, Barnes pulls the ULF REPORT under his arm, hands it to Norman. Norman looks at it, almost embarrassed to be holding it.
Your report's become our bible down here, Dr. Johnson.  We've been carrying out each of your recommendations -- one by one -- to the smallest detail.
But sir, I don't understand.  This report -- these recommendations... they're for an encounter with extra- terrestrial life.
ON A VIDEO SCREEN -- sonar video of the spacecraft.
How big is this spacecraft?
Of what we're able to measure, roughly twenty-six hundred feet.
A half a mile long?

The wing dimension alone is larger that any aircraft we've seen. The team members sit around the conference table: TED FIELDING, 41, geologist, boyish and happy to be here. HALPERIN, 36, biochemist, mother of three who's never wor ARTHUR LEVINE, 54, marine biologist, pudgy and quiet.  HA mathamatician, African-American, wire-glasses, no bullshi
How much damage?
To the craft?  None.  Not a scratch.
Right.  So you're saying it survived a high speed impact with water without a scratch?
I'm not saying anything, Harry, I'm just stating the facts. (continuing)
The outer metal is made of a titanium alloy, built into an epoxy- resin honeycomb.  The necessary technology to bond this type of metal has never been invented.
Never invented? ON NORMAN, watching the team...
In basic English, what does all this mean?
Basic English?  There's no way this spacecraft was constructed on our planet.
A large, X-Ray APPARATUS moves to the side, revealing Nor ON BETH -- standing next to him.
Five years.  No phone calls.  What am I -- a leper? Norman sits up...
Beth, look, can I trust you with a little secret?
I love secrets.
That ULF report everybody's patting me on the back about?
I've read it twice, Norman.  It's brilliant.
It's bullshit.  The report's a joke.
(beat)
That's quite a secret.

I spent a week reading Sagan and watching re-runs of the Twilight Zone.  Seriously.  I was just trying to pay the mortgage on my house -- I had no idea -- ANGLE ON TWO NAVY CORPSMEN, standing behind glass in the monitoring Beth and Norman.
Do yourself a favor, Norman.  Are you listening?  Don't tell anyone what you just told me.
C'mon, Beth -- that report's like the blind leading the blind.
Because when we get down there --
Wait -- down where?
To the spacecraft.  To investigate.
Underwater?
What do you expect?  For them to bring it up here?
We can't go down there.  We're not prepared.  That deep?  That takes years of training, Beth.  We're just scientists.  Lab scietists.  We wear ties and lab coats to work -- not oxygen tanks.
Well, you must have realized the chances an encounter like this would happen here.  In the ocean. (off his look)
70 percent of the earth's surface is water, Norman.  That's first grade geography.
It never occurred to me.
Well, let's pray that's the only mistake you made.  Have you said anything to Barnes about this?
The timing has never seemed quite right.
Just keep your mouth shut, alright? This could mean everything to our careers, you know that?  Don't jeopardize this.
(nervous laughter)
What -- are you threatening me?
THE SKY -- clouds looming on the horizon. ANGLE ON ARTHUR LEVINE, leaning against the railing, look the water. ON NORMAN, approaching him.  Arthur never looks at Norman stares out at the water.
I don't know you, but I'll be honest with you.  I don't like this.  I don't like any of this.  Especially, the water.
Seasick?  A marine biologist?
I don't belong here.  None of us belong here.  Look at that. ANGLE ON THE WATER, an ocean of seemingly endless, choppy
Makes you feel pretty small, doesn't it?
It scares the shit out of me.
CLOSE ON NORMAN, lying on a cot.  It is dark.  His eyes a stares at the ceiling.
A porthole hatch to the DESCENT SUB unlatches loudly.  A help Norman lower himself through the hatch.

Norman steps down the ladder into the sub compartment.  S circle area: Ted, Beth, Harry, and Arthur.  Ahead of them Barnes sits with the pilot in the sub's cockpit, separate of plexiglass. Norman takes a seat between Beth and Ted.
(through the intercom)
Our descent will take 13 minutes. Descending at a speed of 80 feet per minute. Across from Norman, Harry is WHISPERING something quietly Arthur's ear.
Pressure adjustments will cause the sub to lurch at times, but don't be alarmed.  It's perfectly normal... Arthur's face drips with sweat, as Harry continues to whi ear.

The sub's interior atmosphere will experience moisture as we descend, and the temperature will drop rapidly.  Just relax and remain seated during the descent. Norman watches Arthur, dripping with sweat.
We have clearing from the base. Red interior lights flicker on in the compartment, and WE make a HISSING sound.  The sub lurches, and begins to low water.
Arthur? Harry has gotten to Arthur.  Arthur is on the verge of pa
Arthur?  You alright?
Open the hatch door, please. Harry continues to whisper in his ear.
Captain, open the hatch door, please ... the hatch door, Captain.  Open it, please.
Calm down, Dr. Levine.
Let me out, Captain.  Open the door!
Please, Dr. Levine. Arthur leaps violently out of his seat, scrambles to the wall.
(through the plexiglass)
Sit down, Dr. Levine!  You're in a military operation now -- Arthur bangs on the plexiglass wall with his fists.
... Your civil rights have been overridden!
Open it, Captain!
Dr. Levine, please!  Return to your seat! Arthur VOMITS, violently, heaving, splattering the plexig

Open the fucking door! The sub LURCHES again, coming to a stop.  The compartment silent, as they begin ascending to the surface. ON HARRY smiling a sly, evil grin directed right at Norma The sub lurches again, and WE HEAR clanking metal.  The h opens. And Arthur, wiping the vomit from his mouth, climbs up th out the hatch door.
Anybody else? Silence. The hatch door LOCKS, loudly.  The sub lurches, and begin
Pussy.
What's that -- mistake number two, Norman?
He wasn't feeling well.
He's a pussy. Harry is still staring at Norman...
How are you feeling, Norman?
What?
You holding up alright?
Fine.  I'm fine.
Don't be defensive.
I'm not being defensive.
You sound defensive.
I'm fine.
(to Harry)
What'd you say to him?
To who?  Arthur?  Nothing.  Nothing that Norman doesn't already know.
What does Norman already know?
Norman thinks we shouldn't be going down.  Thinks it's a mistake. Norman looks over at Beth.
She told me what you said, Norman.
What is it, Harry?
Just one of Norman's many secrets. ON NORMAN, saying nothing.
WE SEE the sub descending into darker waters.
The SUB descends into the AIRLOCK, metal clanks against m it, the DH-8: interwoven cylinders lit up with lights.
CLOSE ON THE HATCH DOOR closing tightly, locking.
One moment for pressurizing. A SOFT WHIRR. ANGLE ON -- Barnes and the four remaining team members st small, claustrophobic pressurizing room.  Like sardines. anything.  A long beat.

in front of them, opens.  TEENY FLETCHER, 30s, a big-bone officer, stands before them.  She wears a black plastic P "talker", around her neck. She hands each member their own "talker".  Norman takes h
Fletcher leads Barnes and the team members down the hallw them wears the "talkers" around their necks.
They pressurize us with helium.
What's wrong with oxygen?

It's a corrosive gas.  On earth, it makes a half-eaten apple turn brown and puts the ugly, iron rust on an Oldsmobile.  At a pressure this low, oxygen becomes toxic.  Breathe it down here, and it'll do to your dick what it does to the Oldsmobile.
Important safety tip.  Thanks Captain. Fletcher listens through her radio earpiece, turns to Bar
Captain, the divers have the airlock mounted at the door.  The robot is now in position to enter the spacecraft.
Robot?  What robot?
CLOSE ON A MONITOR -- showing the robot in front of the c metal of the spacecraft.
Edmunds, bring up the robot's camera feed. JANE EDMUNDS, 32, the unit archivist, works the control p MONITOR clicks on -- showing the robot's POV of the door.
Captain, you know, I really appreciate you hauling us a thousand feet below sea level so we can watch this historical event on television.
Nobody goes inside, until we know what's inside. ON THE MONITOR -- THE ROBOT CAMERA scans the spacecraft h a rectangular panel mounted to the left of the door.
Can you open that panel?
Working on it now, sir. ON THE MONITOR -- a robotic CLAW extends out to the panel pry the panel open.
I'd like it noted in the report that I think we should be doing this ourselves.  Making a manned entry... The claw is clumsy, and keeps banging into the metal.
I'd also like it noted --
Duly noted, Ted.  Edmunds, try using suction. ON THE MONITOR -- another robotic arm extends out, with a sucker.  It pushes against the panel, but doesn't suck.
It's not sucking, sir.
Thank you, I can see that.  Try something else.
We don't have anything else to try, Sir.
Well, shit -- find something, do something... make something up --
What about a crowbar? Barnes straightens up, looks at Ted...
What  about a crowbar?
What if we go out there, you know -- wedge a crowbar in the door and pry the thing open.
Pry the thing open?  What are we -- neanderthals?
All that banging and pounding.  I don't know.  We should think about making a good first impression.
For who?  The fish?
For whoever's in that thing.
Or whatever's in that thing. ON THE MONITOR -- the spacecraft, sitting there silently, at them.
Norman, what do you think? Norman, quiet in the corner, perks up...
Me?  Well -- I don't really...  I mean, you could... you know, you could make a real solid case... a crowbar? All eyes on Norman.
I don't know. A beat as they all stare at him.
I'm secure enough with that.
ANGLE ON A LOCKER door opening.  Inside is an elaborate J HELMET with the name: "JOHNSON", stenciled above the face
Are we all -- I mean, is it necessary for all of us to go... out there? The other team members take their suits out of their lock

Nothing to be nervous about.  These suits are wired and electrically heated.  Each equipped with an alarm that triggers automatically if life- support sustems go below optimum. Norman holds his jumpsuit out and away from him, like it' nuclear.
It's just like swimming, Norman... You know how to swim, don't you?
You're not afraid of the water, are you, Norman? They all look over at him.
(half smiling)
Isn't there a psychological term for that, Dr. Johnson?
(under his breath)
Yeah.  Drowning.
Dressed in jumpsuits and helmets -- Barnes jumps into a P water, cut out from the floor, leading to the ocean.  It tiny swimming pool.  Ted jumps in next.  Beth, Harry, and left...
You're next, Norman.
(nervous as hell)
No.  Go ahead.  Really.  Ladies first.
Such a gentlemen when you're scared shitless. She hops in.  Norman watches, looks up at Harry, next to
Go ahead.  Ladies first.
No, why don't -- Harry nudges him forward.
C'mon.
Wait a second, I -- Harry pushes him again.  Norman catches himself.
Geez, c'mon, alright.  Gimme a minute.  Let me get my bearings -- Harry pushes him again.
C'mon, Norman.
Look, would you -- And Harry just pushes him in.  Norman slips and falls awk the ocean depths.

Quiet.  Only THE SOUND OF NORMAN -- BREATHING. For a couple beats. Now... NORMAN'S POV -- from inside his helmet -- a light behind him -- casting his SHADOW onto the murky ocean flo Norman's head turns, and he's BLINDED by a light -- it's light SHINING from the top of Harry's helmet. WE HEAR Harry's voice, static, through Norman's helmet.

The switch is on your waist. ON NORMAN -- his GLOVE -- fumbling at his waist. HIS HELMET LIGHT -- FLICKERS on. ON NORMAN -- slowly, beginning to walk on the ocean floor HIS FEET -- squashing gently, lightly into the muddy grou NORMAN'S POV -- can barely make out the others in front o helmet lights STROBING the dark water, crossing each othe searchlights on a foggy night. CLOSE ON NORMAN'S FACE -- eyes cold, BREATHING.  Couple b

Look at that thing. Norman's eyes look up... WE PULL BACK... LONG, HIGH, WIDE SHOT of the team -- their little helmet and insignificant almost as... IN FRONT OF THEM -- the SPACECRAFT.  Dwarfing them in siz large, majestic, like nothing we've ever seen.  The enorm in the distance, extends high out of the coral. In the huge MOUND OF CORAL covering the spacecraft, WE SE cut out like a cave -- lined with tiny, dim lightbulbs.
About 60 feet deep.  Narrower than they'd like.  Norman d clumsily, awkwardly -- pushing off the bulky, iron handle the coral walls.
CLOSE ON NORMAN'S FACE as he watches the water recede, do faceplate.
Ted has wedged a crowbar into the door and BANGS at it wi sledgehammer.
Easy Ted, we're not mining gold.
Gimme some room here, will you?  Back off.  Gimme some space. They all back away, cramming into the far corner of the a keeps swinging.
Looks alot like an airplane door, doesn't it? Ted stops and looks at the door.
Alot like.  You know, I noticed it before, but I didn't...
Shutup, Ted.  You didn't notice shit. Keep hammering.
You want me to try?
You're a 53 year old shrink, what are you gonna do?
Give him the hammer, Ted. Norman takes the hammer.  Walks up to the wedge.  Gets hi Rears back... then stops.
What is it, your back give out? Something has caught Norman's eye.  He looks down at the
What is it, Norman?
Take a look. Barnes comes toward him.  The others follow.  Barnes bend closely down at the wedge in the door.
It's chipped.
Chipped?  The door?  How can it be chipped?
I don't know how it can be chipped, but it's chipped.
I thought you said there wasn't any damage done in the crash?
I did.
Then how can it be chipped? ON BETH -- she touches the door with her palms, feels aro
There's heat coming the door.
Back away then.
Wait a minute --
I said back away.
Would you wait a minute?
Barnes unstraps a GUN -- nearly the size of an uzzi -- fr buckle.
Ted, get her away from the door.
What are you going to do -- shoot her? The RUMBLING louder...

Get her away! THE DOOR begins to slide open. Beth backs away. THE DOOR, sliding, is revealing COMPLETE BLACKNESS inside stops, it's open, it's quiet.  They all stand there, look BLACKNESS.  A long beat.

ON NORMAN -- cautiously stepping inside.  His helmet ligh others ahead of him, walking along a 5 foot wide CATWALK, high in the air. Metallic BEAMS and RAFTERS criss-cross above them. Norman looks over the railing -- his light STROBES throug darkness, dimly lighting the LOWER HULL, a dense network GIRDERS.
Look at this.
What is it? Ted SPOTLIGHTS the OUTER HULL.
Some sort of lead or something.
Radiation shield, you think?
A foot and a half thick?  That'd withstand a helluva lot of radiation. Beth's light SHINES down onto the CATWALK.  WE SEE FOOTPR on the dusty floor.
Hold on --
What is it?
Any of you get ahead of me -- walk this far up?
No.  I don't think so.
Well, think.  Because there's footprints here that aren't mine.
Well, they're not mine. ON THE FOOTPRINTS -- large, like the boots they're wearin
Calm down, alright?  They gotta be somebody's here.  Let's stay together, please.
LONG SHOT -- seeing them suspended high in the air on the walking.  Their tiny streams of LIGHT moving about.  WE S ominous this spacecraft really is.
It's empty.  Why would someone build a ship like this?
You'd have to ask them. They approach a DOOR, at the end of the catwalk.
Alright, Beth, do that thing you did before.
How about I just press the button? She presses a button near the door.  The door SLIDES open
Or just... press the button. Barnes holds out his gun, and enters.  The others behind
Strange, isn't it?  You know -- how it would have a button.
Earth doesn't have a patent on buttons, Ted.
Still, make a note I recognized that. ON BARNES -- leading them through a small hall.  It seems up into some sort of room -- when Barnes stops.  Dead in
What's wrong?
(serious)
What do you make of this? ON NORMAN -- as he steps around Barnes, his light BRIGHTE SIGN that reads: "Trash."
(softly)
What the hell? Very softly, Harry begins to laugh.
English?
That's right. Norman looks up and SEES more of the room as his light SH throughout it: TABLES, COUCHES and CHAIRS -- made of leat comfortable looking. They begin to slowly wander about...
I don't get it.
It doesn't make any sense.
You don't think it does?  I think it's rather obvious.
Is it some sort of joke?  Like one of those hoaxes?
A spacecraft half a mile long -- with 500 tonnes of coral on top of it?  Someone went to a lot of trouble.  Try again.
But it's impossible.
Is it? Beth touches the table, it's metal, but it's soft and rub
Why would this ship carry instructions in English?
Think about it.
Unless, this alien spacecraft was -- you know -- somehow presenting itself to Americans in a way that would make us feel comfortable.
400 years ago?  I'm sure Christopher Columbus would've loved these accomodations.
Good theory, Ted.
Well, what's your theory?
I'm a woman.  I don't theorize.  I only deal with facts.
All the facts you need are right in front of you.
Gimme a minute here... I think I've got it.
Do you?
If it is an alien spacecraft --
Save your breath.  It's not an alien spacecraft.
Then what is it?
(beat)
It's an American spacecraft.
An American spacecraft?  Half a mile long?  And buried 400 years?  Yeah, good theory, Harry.
It's been obvious from the start, hasn't it, Captain?  That's why all the secrecy, why no one was told about it?
We had considered it.
Considered what?  That it's American? How would you think it's American?
The chip in the door. ON NORMAN -- glancing up at Harry...

We take a weeny little wedge, bang on it a couple of times, and bust off a chunk of the metal.  Yet any spacecraft -- even at a low velocity, say 200 miles an hour -- crashes into the water -- it's gonna be like hitting concrete, it would crumple like paper.  But there isn't a dent to be seen anywhere.  Not even a scratch.
Meaning?
Meaning it didn't land in the water.
Please.  It must have flown here --
It didn't fly here.  It  arrived here.
Arrived?  From where?
Not where.  When.  400 years ago.  From our future. A quiet moment as they take this in.
Ted and Barnes trek through a vast cargo bay, like two an flashlights.
Time travel.  I always thought it was one of those myths... like Santa's reindeer.
What would we be working on in the future that would make us want to come back?
Maybe we didn't want to come back.
Norman, Harry, and Beth...
What are you looking for?
A light switch.  A button opened that door -- the craft runs on some sort of power. ON NORMAN -- as he sits down in one of the CHAIRS.
What's that noise? They LISTEN to a GIRGLING NOISE.
Sounds a little like water -- SUDDENLY -- the chair Norman's in -- wraps around him, sq inside, padding sliding around his head, his shoulders en -- sucking him inside...
Norman!
Get this thing off me. Beth bends down, presses a button, the CHAIR releases Nor
I think the chair thinks you want to fly this thing. ON BETH's FACEPLATE -- as she's looking down -- WE BEGIN reflected in her faceplate: yellow digital lettering sput across...
Her EYES look up slowly... as we

THE BLACK SCREEN in front of the chairs, lit up with brig lettering: "RV -- LHOOQ -- DCOMl -- U.S.S STAR VOYAGER" "ASSIMILATING DATABASE" as a series of numbers race upwar count...  And the desk in front of them LIGHTS UP, a control panel life.
Nice work, Norman.
Whatever I can do to help. ON THE SCREEN as it changes, now filled with columns:
Harry punches some keys on the control panel.
A flight recorder.  Our future is about to be seen in our present. ON THE SCREEN as it changes:
01-01-47.  Two thousand-forty seven. 50 years in our future.

Unknown Entry Event. Harry pauses, looks down, and punches more keys...  ON THE SCREEN -- as it expands in size, widens around the WE SEE a galaxy of stars, planets coming OFF THE SCREEN, room, becoming three dimensional, suspended in air, givin illusion of depth. The IMAGE begins streaking outward, TOWARD US, moving rap we're flying through it. The stars and other space matter streaking by.
What's that cluster of stars there? In the center? Harry stares, walking around the desk, moving into the 3-
Our answer.
To what?

Time travel.  A black hole. The CLUSTER of stars grows brighter and brighter, as it c and closer, brightening. The FIELD twists and turns as the SCREEN and FIELD become WE ENTER the cluster, the black hole. ON NORMAN -- his face, bright, FRIGHTENED as he HEARS:
Ted?  Captain?
Yes, Harry.
We know how this craft got here. Where it's been.
So do we.  And it seems to have picked up something on it's travels. STILL ON NORMAN -- frightened...
Picked up something?  What is it?
I don't know.  But it's something alien.

ANGLE ON our six team members' BOOTS, in the distance.  A and AROUND WE SEE a curved surface appear: a surface of s swirling green and blue fluids.  Like mercury.  Mesmerizl AS WE COME AROUND, the team stands looking at the SPHERE, dlameter, held by a GIANT CLAW gripping it from the top. They walk around it, circling it, looking up at it.
This answers one of our questions.

He acquired some sort of power.  A power to manifest things.
But how?
I don't know.
How can the sphere do that?

I don't know, Beth.  I'm not the fucking alien that built the thing. But it can.  When Harry came out of the sphere, he mumbled something about page 87.  How he would never read that far -- he was too scared to.  Then you found the book, remember in your lab.  Then in the cafeteria -- and page 87 talks about a giant squid...
Which I told Barnes was attacking --
It's his fear.  The squid.  He's manifesting his fears.  Making them real.
But why is he doing it?
He must not realize he is.  Like the Navy crewman -- Harry was sleeping then.  He must've manifested his dream.
His dream?  You can't control your dreams.  And you can't control your fears, can you?
(shaking his head)
No.  I mean, we've always believed we can think anything we want without consequences.  You ever read the Bible? (off her look)

It talks about our sinful nature, you know?  I mean, we can think, and believe, and desire whatever we want, but there's a part of us -- a shadow side, as Jung called it -- that can't be controlled.  It's evil. It's inside us.  It's what we are.
It's dark.  Harry lies on his bunk, asleep.
And that's the part of Harry that's being manifested.
Must be.  And if it is -- it's a part of him not even he can control. Harry opens his eyes, stares at us.

Jerry.  Right.  I said Jerry, didn't

I'm sorry.  Slip of the tongue.

Wisconsin?

Navy transmission.  They're sent from Wisconsin.

text: Norman and Beth smile...
The cavalry is on it's way. THE SCREEN -- "16:00:00"... it begins decending in count.
Just in time, too.
In time for what?
What?
Just in time for what? Beth, nervous, tries to cover...
Our habitat, I mean.  This place can't handle another attack.
Another attack? A long beat, as Beth stares at Harry.
Why are you looking at me like that?
Like what?  I'm not --
You're staring at me.
No I'm not.  I'm not star--
Yes you are...  Harry looks at both of them, suspiciously...
Did I miss something?  You two seemed to patch things up awfully fast. A tense beat.
We just figured, you know, the three of us -- we need to... work together through this.
The three of us.
That's right.
(beat)
Is that why the two of you went through my dufflebag? Norman glances at THE SCREEN behind Harry: "I WILL KILL Y
CLOSE ON THE MEDICAL CABINET -- WHIPPING open. Norman quickly digs through the medicines...
Diphenyl parlene.
Something for burns.
Ephedrine hydrochloride. Beth at the computer, looking up the names...
It's for motion sickness.
Valdomet.
Ulcers.
Sintag.
A synthetic opium analogue.
Does it cause drowsiness?  That's all we need.  To get him unconscious -- put him under.
Nothing about drowsiness.
Tarazine?
Tranquilizer.  Causes drowsiness.
Bingo.
"... and may also cause bizarre halucinations". Norman throws it on the floor.  Picks another...
Riordan?
Antihistamine.  For bites.
Damn it!  Chloramphenicol?
Antibiotic.
Parasolutrine?
How do you spell it?
P-a-r-a-s-o...
It's a soporific.
What's that?
Causes sleep.
It's like a sleeping pill?
"... used as an anesthetic if given in combination with paracin trichloride... " Norman digs, finds paracin trichloride...
Here we go.
BETH -- mixing the medicines...
(reading from the computer)
"20 cc's of parasolutrine in combination with 6 cc's of paracin given IV produces deep sleep suitable for emergency surgical procedures... no cardiac side effects ... REM activity is surpressed... "
How long does it last?
Three to six hours.
I'll just boost the doses.
What?  Wait -- isn't that dangerous?
How fast does it take effect?
Doesn't say.
What if it takes 20 minutes, Norman? What if it takes an hour?  And he can fight it off?  We can't afford that. Beth goes to the cabinet, grabs another medicine.  Norman she adds it to the mix...
What is that?  What are you doing? What do you want to do -- kill him? A beat...
It's an idea.
Beth --
To be on the safe side.  I mean --
You want to kill him?
Look, it's either him or us, Norman. Another attack, and we go down with this place. She fills the LARGE SYRINGE with the clear liquid mix.
You ever given an injection before.
Thirty years ago.  In residency.  I passed out.  You?
Only lab rats.  Here. She hands him the syringe...
Give him the whole thing.  Hurry, before he wakes up. Norman looks at the syringe, like it's an assault rifle.
Where do I stick it?
Harry sleeps on his bunk.  The door to the room is closed

shuffling down the corridor, nervously.  Glancing at the
and SEES in front of the Living Quarters...  TWO AFRICAN-AMERICAN NAVY CREWMEN -- standing guard of th Norman stops, hides behind the wall.

Norman and Beth running...
Harry! BANG!  Water shoots through the wall.  Gushing out onto t walls CRACKING. ON HARRY -- running out of his room...

You know what it is, Harry. BANG!  They lose their balance, still running...
It's the squid!  Stop it!
Stop what?  What are you -- ? BANG!  Another CRACK -- water gushing inside.

Doing what?  I'm not doing anything -- ! Beth takes the syringe from her palm, and STABS Harry in

Isotonic glucose supplement. Norman looks at the cup.

It's getting cold.

You don't think I put something in it, do you?
You put explosives around the habitat, I can't imagine what you'd put in a drink.
I did do that, didn't I? A beat.  She picks up the drink, and begins sipping it. her.
How do you feel about snakes?
Snakes?  What do you mean, exactly?
You know what I mean.
Am I afraid of them?  Not during the day.  Sea snakes are diurnal.  When the sun's out, they don't bite. Fortunately for you, I had on my watch. (off cup)
This is quite good.

You tell me.
Do you fear them?
Don't you?
Are you manifesting them?
If I was, then I would've had to have gone in the sphere, wouldn't
Did you?
What's the phrase -- "keeping up with the Joneses"?
Why did you go in the sphere, Beth?
Same reason I put explosives around the habitat.  For defense.  For the power.  To protect myself.
Against what?  Harry's unconscious. He's not a threat.
No, he isn't.
He can't manifest.
No, he can't.
Then why, Beth?  Why go in?  Why put out explosives?  Why manifest the snakes?
You think I manifested the snakes?
Someone did.
Yes, someone did.  But it wasn't me, Norman. (beat)
It was you.  You manifested the snakes. A long beat between them.
Beth you're losing it.  C'mon.
C'mon -- what?
You're lying --
Am I lying?  Are you sure?  Are you absolutely sure I'm lying? (off his look)
Then explain to me about the jellyfish.  Earlier.  Why did we see jellyfish?  Harry doesn't fear jellyfish.  You do.  They're your fear, aren't they?
But --
And the snakes?  You want to know about the snakes?  You saw one outside earlier, didn't you?  When you thought I had deserted you -- you were terrified.
(realizing)
That's when you went in the sphere.
One lonely, terrifying sea snake.
You manifested that, Beth.
Did I?  Or was that you? (beat)

When you were hiding in the bathroom -- all conspiratorially like you were -- you became frightened, didn't you?  Terrified.  Like you were with the snake earlier -- and suddenly you have snakes slithering all over the floor.  You did that, Norman.
You're insane.
Am I?  Or am I making so much sense that you're going insane?
I never went in that sphere.
You don't remember you did.  But I'm sure you remember running like some fucking hero to get Harry, don't you?  You remember that.
Yes.
You remember before you picked him up -- when you looked up at the sphere, you remember that -- when the sphere opened? (off his look)
That's right.  But you can't remember going inside, can you?  No, of course not.  Harry couldn't either, could he?  "Like everything's on the tip of my tongue", he said.
That's bullshit.
Is it?

No, it isn't.  Your name is Norman. But your younger brother -- what was his name?  The one who was stung when you were younger.  The one that died. The one you couldn't save.  What was his name? (imitating)
"Mommy, we're going out to the ocean -- to go swimming." "But I don't want to go swimming, Norman.  I'm scared." "C'mon,  Harry , it'll be fine, it'll be fun." (resuming)
You heartless fuck.  That's why you're so scared of the water, isn't it?
Shut up, Beth --

When you were in that sub -- and that squid was attacking you -- are you sure it was the squid that was attacking?  Do you know?  "I can't get Beth on the radio.  I'm in this tiny sub on the bottom of the fucking ocean.  All alone.  Surrounded by all this water." Was it really the squid that was attacking you, Norman -- or was it something else -- one of your fears?  You never really saw what it was, did you? Norman stares up at her, frightened.  Is she right?
I'm not scaring you, am I Norman?  I hope I'm not frightening you.  The last thing I want to do is frighten you.  You feel okay, don't you?
It's not me, Beth.  I swear.  It can't be.
"It's not me, Beth.  It's not me.  It can't be.  I'm not doing anything." Just like Harry said before I stabbed him with the needle. Norman looks at her palm -- SEES the NEEDLE in her hand. up, away.

I promise --
Promise what, Norman?  Tell me!
Beth --
You think I'd belive you?  Believe anything you might say now?  After you lied to me about telling Barnes about my past.  About my problems.  My problems.  Not yours.  Not his.  Mine.
Don't, Beth.  Please.
It's either this... or I kill you. The GUN in her other hand.
Beth -- She comes at him, needle in hand...
It's your choice.  Because it's not safe for you to be awake.  To be walking around.  To be thinking about things.
It's not safe for you to be either.
You think I care?  You think I care if I die? (almost laughing)

Would I put explosives around the habitat -- set on vibration sensors -- that can trigger automatically, if I cared about myself?  Would I? I've tried twice before, Norman, why wouldn't I try a third time?  I'm not thinking about myself -- No, Norman, I'm thinking about you.  Your safety. Protecting you from your own self. Norman!  I'm doing this for you, Norman. He frantically crawls up the stairs, her grasping at his

Come here, Norman. She GRABS his ANKLE.  She raises the NEEDLE.  Norman turn the FACE. She WAILS, blood SPITTING from her nose. Climbing, climbing.  The STAIRS increasing above.  He LUN step, GRABS it.  Pulls himself up...
Scrambling.  He stares down at Beth -- the GUN pointing a

Get away from the door, Beth. He slides a heavy FILE CABINET over on top of the door.
Oh, Norman, I don't want to come in...  The door's METAL PIVOT turns...

... I want to lock you in.

Turn off the water, Beth. The entire floor is covered in water, rising higher, and

Beth, stop it!
Stop what?  Don't blame me.  It's not me. Norman frantically checking for a crack, a leak.

From you, Norman.  From your mind. You're doing it. It's up to his waist.  He climbs on top a lab bench.  Put his temples, straining.  WE HEAR Beth laughing. A SPECIMEN BOTTLE -- EXPLODES right next to him.
